posts.cooked:
Attempting to use robotpy 2022, got the following error when trying to deploy:

OSError: libCTRE_Phoenix.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

Our steps:

Our roboRio (v1) had been running 2021 robotpy and we had been able to deploy & run

We upgraded the firmware to 2022 (FRC_roboRIO_2022_v3.0

We updated the Python install on the robot to 3.10

We downloaded latest robotpy and installed on the robot

We downloaded latest robotpy[ctre] and installed on the robot

We downloaded latest robotpy[navx] and installed on the robot

We tried deploying the same robot.py that ran before (very simple tank drive) and got the error above.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: I’m able to reproduce the issue locally. Should be able to push out a fix shortly.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Fix is pushed as robotpy-ctre 2022.0.2 … probably will take 20 minutes to get through CI. Track the build at https://github.com/robotpy/robotpy-ctre/actions/runs/1715341651
Awesome, thanks for the quick turn-around! Will let you know how this goes next time we have a chance to test.

Updated to the robotpy 2022.0.14 and tried deploying our simple tank drive code which had worked before on 2021, but got the error below.

Note that upon upgrading to 2022.0.14, we needed to then upgrade the Talon firmware, which we did.

Here is our code:

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
Another user reported a segfault with the RobotPy CTRE bindings @ https://github.com/robotpy/robotpy-ctre/issues/142 . It appears that our CTRE bindings are pretty broken right now due to a potential regression with how pybind11 handles virtual/multiple inheritance.

It’ll be potentially tricky to fix, so I wouldn’t expect a fix until the weekend at the very earliest. Sorry about that. Recommend going back to 2021 for the moment.
Got it, thanks, back on 2021 for the moment!

Are we correct to interpret from the issues being closed in Github that the RobotPy CTRE is back in business for 2022? Or is it still unknown / waiting for someone to test it?

Since it takes a fair amount of our limited lab time to switch from 2021 - 2022 and back, figured we’d check here first to see if we should still hold off, or go for it and give it another try now.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Sorry for not getting back to this thread. Yes, robotpy-ctre should be functional now.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
